awd_titl_txt: Deep ocean internal wave generation in weak stratification
awd_abstract_narration:
PI:  Crockett, Julie
Proposal Number: 1606040

The concentration of salt in the ocean changes with depth. This fact generates waves within the water that are called internal waves. The breaking of these waves drives much of the mixing in the deep ocean, defining mixing rates of pollutants, greenhouse gases, ocean nutrients and maintaining a balanced temperature distribution. It has been estimated that 2.1 terawatts of mixing power is required to maintain critical ocean mixing. Over half of the necessary power is postulated to come from internal waves generated by tidal flow over rough topography. The waves propagate through interactions with other waves and with ocean currents, until they convert to smaller scale, breaking waves. The focus of this proposal is to use laboratory experiments to study this process of internal wave generation and to understand how internal waves are generated and propagated within the ocean system. Findings from this research could lead to the development of new large scale ocean models that are important for the prediction of aquatic life migration patterns, for the prediction of the dispersion of pollutants in the ocean (like the dispersion of the radioactive spill from the Fukushima accident) and for the prediction of weather and climate patterns.

An unexpected contributor to internal wave generation is tides flowing over topography in regions where the stratification is too weak for internal waves to be generated directly above the topography, yet internal waves can be observed well above the topography in a region where the stratification has increased. These waves may contribute to the conversion of tidal energy from large to small scales, which has important environmental consequences for wave-breaking and resultant mixing. The work proposed here is an experimental and analytical effort to characterize a relatively unexplored method of internal wave generation - the generation of internal waves due to tidal flow over topography in regions of weak stratification (where internal waves are not predicted to propagate) which radiate into strong stratification regions with implications for characterizing the internal wave energy spectrum throughout the ocean. It is proposed to: 1) explore internal wave generation by both uniform and tidal flow over topography in a two-layer stratification profile using experimentation; 2) characterize the effect of variations in stratification profile on internal wave generation, where for all stratification profiles the topography is in a region of weak stratification, such that internal waves are not expected, with a stronger stratification above; and 3) create an analytical model of the energy propagation from the topography through the variable stratification including the region representing evanescent to propagating waves. The project will contribute to the development of experimental methodology and understanding of stratified flow dynamics which will inform large scale modeling systems, resulting in better wave generation, propagation, and dissipation estimates. On the educational side, the project will support a research program of a professor from an under-represented group and training of graduate and undergraduate students in the ideas, concepts and practice of fluid dynamics, physical oceanography, internal wave theory, experimental methodology, and data analysis. The research will also be highlighted in high school and lower-division outreach activities and in upper-division courses.

por.por_cntn:
Internal waves are formed in regions where the density increases continuously with depth, such as the ocean. Disturbances to the density variation cause a ripple effect and three-dimensional internal waves are generated which can propagate throughout the medium, altering currents and mixing in the ocean. It is hypothesized that internal wave breaking is responsible for half the energy dissipation in the ocean. Thus, it is paramount to understand how these waves are generated, propagate, and eventually break and cause mixing.

This project was an analytical and experimental exploration of internal wave generation by tidal flow over topography in regions of relatively low stratification (small buoyancy frequency). These regions are important as they have been overlooked as strong internal wave generation sites since for buoyancy frequencies less than that of the wave generating mechanism, exponentially decaying disturbances termed evanescent waves are formed. However, just above these regions the stratification often increases such that evanescent waves will become propagating waves as they move upward. This transition is a turning depth. We explored the conditions of evanescent waves reaching turning depths and becoming propagating waves, which will impact the overall global circulation and mixing dynamics within the ocean.

To model a range of ocean conditions, topographic shapes and stratification profiles with increasing complexity were used to better understand their incremental impact on internal wave generation and transmission through the turning depth. Results show using an average stratification in each region for the more complex profiles compared well with the two-layer scenario, which allows for faster computations in the future.

Experiments were accomplished in a long, thin, salt-stratified water tank to simulate 2-D flow. Both synthetic schlieren (SS), which uses the varying index of refraction due to differences in salinity to estimate motion, and particle image velocimetry (PIV) methods were employed. SS was the dominate method used due to its ease of setup, but PIV data showed comparable results, which also allowed us to show the capability of the relatively cheap and easy SS methodology. All experiments were analyzed to define the total kinetic energy density which extended from the generating topography, through the evanescent region, and into the propagating region. Thus, a transmission rate through the turning depth as a function of topography shape, stratification, and relative distance from the turning depth was generated. This rate was significant for a range of scenarios, but decayed as distance to the turning depth increased and stratification strength decreased. In addition, the results were processed to show the characteristic makeup of the internal wavefield - wavelength, frequency, and amplitude - which allows better understanding of the waves that will subsequently be propagating throughout the ocean.

In addition, linear mathematical models were extended to compare experimental results with analytical solutions. We found good agreement between the experiments and analytical model and were able to design a process to accurately follow the energy from the evanescent to propagating region by use of an Airy function to patch over the nonlinearity at this interface. The resulting equations may be used to solve any shape or stratification profile easily if it can be defined by a mathematical equation.

Experimental and analytical results showed the importance of including deep ocean regions in wave generation estimates. For realistic scenarios, up to 40% of the generated wave energy may be transmitted through a turning depth to propagating waves. A new correlation for regions with known bathymetry and stratification profiles was generated to allow a direct estimate of transmission rates within about 10%. In addition, a simple set of rules was put forth to quickly determine if very little energy transmission would occur and the region could be neglected. This will allow much better estimates of internal wave generation and consequently energy dissipation within the ocean as well. Currently, weather and climate models cannot account for each of the billions of internal waves propagating throughout the ocean, but these results will benefit those fields since general dissipation models are made from expected wavefields.

Multiple graduate, undergraduate, and K-12 students were all impacted by this work. Over the course of the research, nine undergraduate students (5 female) were heavily involved in the laboratory setup, testing, and analysis. They also learned about a range of environmental flows, in addition to those needed specifically for this research, as a part of lab meetings and one on one mentoring. Three graduate students (1 female PhD) were also trained in the methods of synthetic schlieren, particle image velocimetry, wave analysis, and multiple laboratory techniques. These students, along with the PI, also ran outreach activities for dozens of K-12 students both in the laboratory and the community to introduce them to the joys of science and help them look at the environment in which they live in a new light.
